ChinaDepartment of BiologyLiuhang Middle School272100JiningP. R. ChinaHandongYin@lctu.edu.cn6520063200616183893112006652006© Springer Science+Business Media, Inc. 20062006

Two types of diorganotins [R2Sn(OCOC5H3N-3-Br-5)2]n and {[R2Sn(OH2)(OCOC5H3N-3-Br-5)2]2}n (R= Me, n-Bu, Ph, n-Oc), are prepared from 5-Br-omonicotinic acid and diorganotin oxides. All the compounds, 1–8, are characterized by elemental analysis as well as IR and 1H-NMR spectroscopy. The crystal structures of [R2Sn(OCOC5H3N-3-Br-5)2]n(2) and {[R2Sn(OH2)(OCOC5H3N-3-Br-5)2]2}n(8) were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. In compound 2, each carboxylate moiety of 5-Br-omonicotinic acid is involved in coordination to one Sn atom via two O-atoms, and the N-atom of one pyridine-ring coordinates to the neighboring Sn atom which leads to a polymeric chain. And the N-atom of the other pyridine-ring is dissociative. In compound 8, the compound proves to be dinuclear macrocyclic compounds with 5-Br-omonicotinic acid bridging the adjacent tin atoms with a 12-member ring. The hydrogen bonds ( \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\hbox{N}\ldots\hbox{H}-\hbox{O}$$\end{document}) are observed in the compound 8. These intermolecular hydrogen bonds form another ring, and lead to a polymeric chain in the lattice at the same time.

Introduction

The environmental and biological chemisty of Organotin(IV) compounds have been the subjects of interest for some time due to their increasingly widespread use [1, 2]. Organotin(IV) carboxylates have attracted much attention owing to their potential biocidal activity [3, 4] and cytotoxicity [5] as well as their industrial and agricultural applications [6–10]. Recently, pharmaceutical properties of organotin esters of carboxylic acids have been investigated for their antitumour activity [11]. It has been revealed that organotin compounds containing carboxylate ligands with additional donor atoms (e.g. N, O or S) that are available for coordinating to the tin atom may result in new structure types, which may lead to different activities [12–15]. From the structural viewpoint, similar to thiosalicylic acid, 5-Br-omonicotinic acid can potentially be a monodentate, bidentate and tridentate ligand; it may also participate as an intermolecularly bridging or intramolecularly chelating ligand. In the present work, we have synthesized eight new polymeric, linear, infinite-chain diorganotin compounds with 5-Br-omonicotinic acid (Scheme 1). All the compounds (1–8) were characterized by elemental analysis and IR and 1H-NMR spectroscopy. The structure of 2 and 8 has been determined by X-ray diffraction.

ExperimentalMaterials and Instrumentation

Dimethyltin oxide, di-n-butyltin oxide, diphenyltin oxide, di-n-Octyltin oxide and 5-Br-omonicotinic acid were commercially available, and were purchased from ACROS. They were used without further purification. The melting points were obtained with a Kofler micro-melting point apparatus and uncorrected. Infrared spectra (FTIR) were recorded on a Nicolet-460 spectrophotometer using KBr discs and sodium chloride optics. 1H-NMR spectra were obtained on a Mercury Plus-400 spectrometer and chemical shifts are given in ppm relative to Me4Si in CDC13. Elemental analyses were performed with a PE-2400II apparatus.

Synthesis of Compounds 1–8

The compounds were synthesized using procedure as shown in Scheme 1.

A mixture of diorganotin oxide (1.0 mmol) and 5-Br-omonicotinic acid (2.0 mmol) was refluxed in 30 ml dry benzene for 6–7 h. The water liberated was removed azeotropically by use of a Dean-Stark apparatus. The clear solution obtained after filtration was evaporated in vacuum to give a white solid. The products (1–4) were recrystallized from dichloromethane–hexane to give colorless crystals.

Then, the products (1–4) were dissolved in 20 ml ethanol (EtOH:H2O=9:1) and refluxed for 3 h, respectively. The clear solution obtained after filtration was evaporated in vacuum to give a white solid. The products (5–8) were then recrystallized from methanol to give colorless crystals.

Found: C, 30.48; H, 2.23; N, 5.08. 1H-NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3), δ ppm (multiplicity, integration, assignment): 8.58–9.23 (m, 6H, Py–H), 0.84 (m, 6H, Sn–CH3). X-ray Structure Determination

Crystals were mounted on Lindemann capillaries under nitrogen. All X-ray crystallographic data were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD 1000 diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ=0. 71073 Å) at room temperature. A semi-empirical absorption correction was applied to the data. The structures were solved by direction methods and refined against F2 by full-matrix least squares using SHELXL-97. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions. Crystallographic data and experimental details of the structure determinations are listed in Table I.

Results and discussion

The assignment of FTIR bands of the title compounds has been made in comparison with the IR spectra related organotin compounds, 5-Br-omonicotinic acid and diorganotin oxides. The free 5-Br-omonicotinic acid shows a broad O–H absorption at 3000–2600 cm −1. This is commonly observed in carboxylic acids [16] but is absent from the spectra of the compounds 1–4. This indicates a deprotonation of the COOH groups during the reaction. All the compounds 5–8 show a broad O–H absorption at 3400∼2650 cm−1. In the far-IR spectra, the absorption in the 478–497 cm−1 region for all the compounds 1–8, which is absent in the spectrum of the ligand, is assigned to the Sn–N stretching vibration.

Regarding the 1H-NMR spectra, the resonance appearing at 10–13 ppm in the free ligand is absent in the 5-Br-omonicotinatodiorganotin compounds (1–4), indicating replacement of the proton of carboxylic acid. But it reappears in the 5-Br-omonicotinatodiorganotin compounds (5–8), owing to O-atom of the water coordinating to the tin atom. This result agrees well with the FTIR spectra. Moreover, the 1H-NMR spectra show that the chemical shifts of R group (Sn–R) in 1–8 are connected directly to tin. All these data are similar to the cases that appear in the literature [17].

An unambiguous assignment of the structure for compounds 2 and 8 are afforded from single crystal X-ray structural analyses. The X-ray diffraction investigation of the two compounds, [n-Bu2Sn(OCOC5H3N-3-Br-5)2]n and {[n-Oc2Sn(OH2)(OCOC5H3N-3-Br-5)2]2}n, indicate that the structure is a polymeric chain in the solid state (as shown in Figs. 5 and 6). The molecular structure and unit cell of compounds 2 and 8 are shown in Figs. 1–4. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables II and III.

In compound 2 (Fig. 1), each carboxylate moiety of 5-Br-omonicotinic acid is involved in coordination to one Sn atom via two O-atoms, and the N-atom of one pyridine-ring coordinates to the neighboring Sn atom which leads to a polymeric chain (Fig. 5). And the N-atom of the other pyridine-ring is dissociative. The minimum repeating unit is composed of a group that contains only one Sn atom. Each Sn atom center is seven-coordinate and exists in a pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with the C-atoms occupying the axial sites. The C(13)-Sn(1)-C(17) angle is 169.81(18)°. The bond lengths of Sn(l)–O(2) and Sn(1)–O(4) in compound 2 (2.523(3) Å and 2.432(3) Å) are longer than that in {[nBu2Sn(2-pic)]2O}2 (2.0544 Å and 2.110 Å) [12] and (PhCH2)3SnO2CC5H4N-4 (2.142 Å) [18] and Me3SnO2C5H4N·H20 (2.18 Å and 2.21 Å) [19].

In compound 8 (Fig. 3), the compound proves to be dinuclear macrocyclic compound with two 5-Br-omonicotinic acid groups bridging the adjacent tin atoms with a 12-member ring via one O-atoms of carboxylate group and the N-atom of the pyridine-ring coordinates to the neighboring tin atoms, mutually. The bond length of Sn(1)–N(2)#1 is 2.751(15) Å. The minimum repeating unit is composed of a group that contains two tin atoms. Each Sn atom center is seven-coordinate and exists in a pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with the C-atoms occupying the axial sites, too. The C(13)-Sn(1)-C(21) angle is 158.1(8)°. Unlike compound 2, in compound 8, one hydroxy O-atom replaces one O-atom of carboxylate group. The Sn(l)–O(5) bond length is 2.141(10) Å. As shown in Fig. 4, intramolecular hydrogen bonds and intermolecular hydrogen bonds are observed in the compound 8. \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\hbox{O}(5)\ldots\hbox{N}(1)\#2$$\end{document} distance of the intermolecular hydrogen bond is 2.709(15) Å. Detailed hydrogen bonds of the complex are listed in Table IV. These intermolecular hydrogen bonds form a six-member ring, and lead to a polymeric chain in the lattice at the same time.

Supplementary material

Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) for the structures reported in this study have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center as supplementary publication No. CCDC 283188 and 283187. Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to the Director, CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge, CB2 1EZ, UK(Fax: +44-1223-336033; E-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk or http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

All X-ray crystallographic data were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD 1000 diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0. 71073 Å) at room temperature. A semi-empirical absorption correction was applied to the data. The structures were solved by direction methods and refined against F2 by full-matrix least squares using SHELXL-97. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions. Crystallographic data and experimental details of the structure determinations are listed in Table I.Results and discussionThe assignment of FTIR bands of the title compounds has been made in comparison with the IR spectra related organotin compounds, 5-Br-omonicotinic acid and diorganotin oxides. The free 5-Br-omonicotinic acid shows a broad O-H absorption at 3000-2600 cm -1. This is commonly observed in carboxylic acids [16] but is absent from the spectra of the compounds 1-4. This indicates a deprotonation of the COOH groups during the reaction. All the compounds 5-8 show a broad O-H absorption at 3400~2650 cm-1. In the far-IR spectra, the absorption in the 478-497 cm-1 region for all the compounds 1-8, which is absent in the spectrum of the ligand, is assigned to the Sn-N stretching vibration.Regarding the 1H-NMR spectra, the resonance appearing at 10-13 ppm in the free ligand is absent in the 5-Br-omonicotinatodiorganotin compounds (1-4), indicating replacement of the proton of carboxylic acid. But it reappears in the 5-Br-omonicotinatodiorganotin compounds (5-8), owing to O-atom of the water coordinating to the tin atom. This result agrees well with the FTIR spectra. Moreover, the 1H-NMR spectra show that the chemical shifts of R group (Sn-R) in 1-8 are connected directly to tin. All these data are similar to the cases that appear in the literature [17].An unambiguous assignment of the structure for compounds 2 and 8 are afforded from single crystal X-ray structural analyses. The X-ray diffraction investigation of the two compounds, [n-Bu2Sn(OCOC5H3N-3-Br-5)2]n and {[n-Oc2Sn(OH2)(OCOC5H3N-3-Br-5)2]2}n, indicate that the structure is a polymeric chain in the solid state (as shown in Figs. 5 and 6). The molecular structure and unit cell of compounds 2 and 8 are shown in Figs. 1-4. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables II and III.In compound 2 (Fig. 1), each carboxylate moiety of 5-Br-omonicotinic acid is involved in coordination to one Sn atom via two O-atoms, and the N-atom of one pyridine-ring coordinates to the neighboring Sn atom which leads to a polymeric chain (Fig. 5). And the N-atom of the other pyridine-ring is dissociative. The minimum repeating unit is composed of a group that contains only one Sn atom. Each Sn atom center is seven-coordinate and exists in a pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with the C-atoms occupying the axial sites. The C(13)-Sn(1)-C(17) angle is 169.81(18)°. The bond lengths of Sn(l)-O(2) and Sn(1)-O(4) in compound 2 (2.523(3) Å and 2.432(3) Å) are longer than that in {[nBu2Sn(2-pic)]2O}2 (2.0544 Å and 2.110 Å) [12] and (PhCH2)3SnO2CC5H4N-4 (2.142 Å) [18] and Me3SnO2C5H4N⋅H20 (2.18 Å and 2.21 Å) [19].In compound 8 (Fig. 3), the compound proves to be dinuclear macrocyclic compound with two 5-Br-omonicotinic acid groups bridging the adjacent tin atoms with a 12-member ring via one O-atoms of carboxylate group and the N-atom of the pyridine-ring coordinates to the neighboring tin atoms, mutually. The bond length of Sn(1)-N(2)#1 is 2.751(15) Å. The minimum repeating unit is composed of a group that contains two tin atoms. Each Sn atom center is seven-coordinate and exists in a pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with the C-atoms occupying the axial sites, too. The C(13)-Sn(1)-C(21) angle is 158.1(8)°. Unlike compound 2, in compound 8, one hydroxy O-atom replaces one O-atom of carboxylate group. The Sn(l)-O(5) bond length is 2.141(10) Å. As shown in Fig. 4, intramolecular hydrogen bonds and intermolecular hydrogen bonds are observed in the compound 8. \documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$\hbox{O}(5)\ldots\hbox{N}(1)\#2$$\end{document} distance of the intermolecular hydrogen bond is 2.709(15) Å. Detailed hydrogen bonds of the complex are listed in Table IV. These intermolecular hydrogen bonds form a six-member ring, and lead to a polymeric chain in the lattice at the same time.Supplementary materialCrystallographic data (excluding structure factors) for the structures reported in this study have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center as supplementary publication No. CCDC 283188 and 283187. elements.content: The environmental and biological chemisty of Organotin(IV) compounds have been the subjects of interest for some time due to their increasingly widespread use [1, 2]. Organotin(IV) carboxylates have attracted much attention owing to their potential biocidal activity [3, 4] and cytotoxicity [5] as well as their industrial and agricultural applications [6–10]. Recently, pharmaceutical properties of organotin esters of carboxylic acids have been investigated for their antitumour activity [11]. It has been revealed that organotin compounds containing carboxylate ligands with additional donor atoms (e.g. N, O or S) that are available for coordinating to the tin atom may result in new structure types, which may lead to different activities [12–15]. From the structural viewpoint, similar to thiosalicylic acid, 5-Br-omonicotinic acid can potentially be a monodentate, bidentate and tridentate ligand; it may also participate as an intermolecularly bridging or intramolecularly chelating ligand. In the present work, we have synthesized eight new polymeric, linear, infinite-chain diorganotin compounds with 5-Br-omonicotinic acid (Scheme 1). All the compounds (1–8) were characterized by elemental analysis and IR and 1H-NMR spectroscopy. The structure of 2 and 8 has been determined by X-ray diffraction.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The environmental and biological chemisty of Organotin(IV) compounds have been the subjects of interest for some time due to their increasingly widespread use [1, 2]. Organotin(IV) carboxylates have attracted much attention owing to their potential biocidal activity [3, 4] and cytotoxicity [5] as well as their industrial and agricultural applications [6-10]. Recently, pharmaceutical properties of organotin esters of carboxylic acids have been investigated for their antitumour activity [11]. It has been revealed that organotin compounds containing carboxylate ligands with additional donor atoms (e.g. N, O or S) that are available for coordinating to the tin atom may result in new structure types, which may lead to different activities [12-15]. From the structural viewpoint, similar to thiosalicylic acid, 5-Br-omonicotinic acid can potentially be a monodentate, bidentate and tridentate ligand; it may also participate as an intermolecularly bridging or intramolecularly chelating ligand. In the present work, we have synthesized eight new polymeric, linear, infinite-chain diorganotin compounds with 5-Br-omonicotinic acid (Scheme 1). All the compounds (1-8) were characterized by elemental analysis and IR and 1H-NMR spectroscopy. The structure of 2 and 8 has been determined by X-ray diffraction.
Scheme 1.

elements.content: Dimethyltin oxide, di-n-butyltin oxide, diphenyltin oxide, di-n-Octyltin oxide and 5-Br-omonicotinic acid were commercially available, and were purchased from ACROS. They were used without further purification. The melting points were obtained with a Kofler micro-melting point apparatus and uncorrected. Infrared spectra (FTIR) were recorded on a Nicolet-460 spectrophotometer using KBr discs and sodium chloride optics. 1H-NMR spectra were obtained on a Mercury Plus-400 spectrometer and chemical shifts are given in ppm relative to Me4Si in CDC13. Elemental analyses were performed with a PE-2400II apparatus.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and Instrumentation

Dimethyltin oxide, di-n-butyltin oxide, diphenyltin oxide, di-n-Octyltin oxide and 5-Br-omonicotinic acid were commercially available, and were purchased from ACROS. They were used without further purification. The melting points were obtained with a Kofler micro-melting point apparatus and uncorrected. Infrared spectra (FTIR) were recorded on a Nicolet-460 spectrophotometer using KBr discs and sodium chloride optics. 1H-NMR spectra were obtained on a Mercury Plus-400 spectrometer and chemical shifts are given in ppm relative to Me4Si in CDC13. Elemental analyses were performed with a PE-2400II apparatus.

elements.content:
The compounds were synthesized using procedure as shown in Scheme 1.

A mixture of diorganotin oxide (1.0 mmol) and 5-Br-omonicotinic acid (2.0 mmol) was refluxed in 30 ml dry benzene for 6–7 h. The water liberated was removed azeotropically by use of a Dean-Stark apparatus. The clear solution obtained after filtration was evaporated in vacuum to give a white solid. The products (1–4) were recrystallized from dichloromethane–hexane to give colorless crystals.

Then, the products (1–4) were dissolved in 20 ml ethanol (EtOH:H2O=9:1) and refluxed for 3 h, respectively. The clear solution obtained after filtration was evaporated in vacuum to give a white solid. The products (5–8) were then recrystallized from methanol to give colorless crystals.

elements.content: Crystals were mounted on Lindemann capillaries under nitrogen. All X-ray crystallographic data were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD 1000 diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ=0. 71073 Å) at room temperature. A semi-empirical absorption correction was applied to the data. The structures were solved by direction methods and refined against F2 by full-matrix least squares using SHELXL-97. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions. Crystallographic data and experimental details of the structure determinations are listed in Table I.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determination

Crystals were mounted on Lindemann capillaries under nitrogen. All X-ray crystallographic data were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD 1000 diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0. 71073 Å) at room temperature. A semi-empirical absorption correction was applied to the data. The structures were solved by direction methods and refined against F2 by full-matrix least squares using SHELXL-97. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions. Crystallographic data and experimental details of the structure determinations are listed in Table I.

The assignment of FTIR bands of the title compounds has been made in comparison with the IR spectra related organotin compounds, 5-Br-omonicotinic acid and diorganotin oxides. The free 5-Br-omonicotinic acid shows a broad O–H absorption at 3000–2600 cm −1. This is commonly observed in carboxylic acids [16] but is absent from the spectra of the compounds 1–4. This indicates a deprotonation of the COOH groups during the reaction. All the compounds 5–8 show a broad O–H absorption at 3400∼2650 cm−1. In the far-IR spectra, the absorption in the 478–497 cm−1 region for all the compounds 1–8, which is absent in the spectrum of the ligand, is assigned to the Sn–N stretching vibration.
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The assignment of FTIR bands of the title compounds has been made in comparison with the IR spectra related organotin compounds, 5-Br-omonicotinic acid and diorganotin oxides. The free 5-Br-omonicotinic acid shows a broad O-H absorption at 3000-2600 cm -1. This is commonly observed in carboxylic acids [16] but is absent from the spectra of the compounds 1-4. This indicates a deprotonation of the COOH groups during the reaction. All the compounds 5-8 show a broad O-H absorption at 3400~2650 cm-1. In the far-IR spectra, the absorption in the 478-497 cm-1 region for all the compounds 1-8, which is absent in the spectrum of the ligand, is assigned to the Sn-N stretching vibration.

elements.content: Regarding the 1H-NMR spectra, the resonance appearing at 10–13 ppm in the free ligand is absent in the 5-Br-omonicotinatodiorganotin compounds (1–4), indicating replacement of the proton of carboxylic acid. But it reappears in the 5-Br-omonicotinatodiorganotin compounds (5–8), owing to O-atom of the water coordinating to the tin atom. This result agrees well with the FTIR spectra. Moreover, the 1H-NMR spectra show that the chemical shifts of R group (Sn–R) in 1–8 are connected directly to tin. All these data are similar to the cases that appear in the literature [17].

elements.content: An unambiguous assignment of the structure for compounds 2 and 8 are afforded from single crystal X-ray structural analyses. The X-ray diffraction investigation of the two compounds, [n-Bu2Sn(OCOC5H3N-3-Br-5)2]n and {[n-Oc2Sn(OH2)(OCOC5H3N-3-Br-5)2]2}n, indicate that the structure is a polymeric chain in the solid state (as shown in Figs. 5 and 6). The molecular structure and unit cell of compounds 2 and 8 are shown in Figs. 1–4. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables II and III.

The molecular structure and unit cell of compounds 2 and 8 are shown in Figs. 1-4. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables II and III.

In compound 2 (Fig. 1), each carboxylate moiety of 5-Br-omonicotinic acid is involved in coordination to one Sn atom via two O-atoms, and the N-atom of one pyridine-ring coordinates to the neighboring Sn atom which leads to a polymeric chain (Fig. 5). And the N-atom of the other pyridine-ring is dissociative. The minimum repeating unit is composed of a group that contains only one Sn atom. Each Sn atom center is seven-coordinate and exists in a pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with the C-atoms occupying the axial sites. The C(13)-Sn(1)-C(17) angle is 169.81(18)°. The bond lengths of Sn(l)–O(2) and Sn(1)–O(4) in compound 2 (2.523(3) Å and 2.432(3) Å) are longer than that in {[nBu2Sn(2-pic)]2O}2 (2.0544 Å and 2.110 Å) [12] and (PhCH2)3SnO2CC5H4N-4 (2.142 Å) [18] and Me3SnO2C5H4N·H20 (2.18 Å and 2.21 Å) [19].

And the N-atom of the other pyridine-ring is dissociative. The minimum repeating unit is composed of a group that contains only one Sn atom. The bond lengths of Sn(l)-O(2) and Sn(1)-O(4) in compound 2 (2.523(3) Å and 2.432(3) Å) are longer than that in {[nBu2Sn(2-pic)]2O}2 (2.0544 Å and 2.110 Å) [12] and (PhCH2)3SnO2CC5H4N-4 (2.142 Å) [18] and Me3SnO2C5H4N⋅H20 (2.18 Å and 2.21 Å) [19].

elements.content: In compound 8 (Fig. 3), the compound proves to be dinuclear macrocyclic compound with two 5-Br-omonicotinic acid groups bridging the adjacent tin atoms with a 12-member ring via one O-atoms of carboxylate group and the N-atom of the pyridine-ring coordinates to the neighboring tin atoms, mutually. The bond length of Sn(1)–N(2)#1 is 2.751(15) Å. The minimum repeating unit is composed of a group that contains two tin atoms. Each Sn atom center is seven-coordinate and exists in a pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with the C-atoms occupying the axial sites, too. The C(13)-Sn(1)-C(21) angle is 158.1(8)°. Unlike compound 2, in compound 8, one hydroxy O-atom replaces one O-atom of carboxylate group. The Sn(l)–O(5) bond length is 2.141(10) Å. As shown in Fig. 4, intramolecular hydrogen bonds and intermolecular hydrogen bonds are observed in the compound 8. \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\hbox{O}(5)\ldots\hbox{N}(1)\#2$$\end{document} distance of the intermolecular hydrogen bond is 2.709(15) Å. Detailed hydrogen bonds of the complex are listed in Table IV. These intermolecular hydrogen bonds form a six-member ring, and lead to a polymeric chain in the lattice at the same time.
